publicationStmt.p: This is an XML-TEI markup of the original publications by SIL Mexico for the purposes of: archival and for the creation of a body of Mixtepec-Mixtec language resources (LR) (ISO: mix). Encoded documents used with the permission of original authors.

notesStmt.note: Cuenta la leyenda que una mujer casada se fue con otro hombre. Su esposo los vio desde una loma, y cuando se sentaron a descansar, les disparó con flechas y los mató. Se dice que tres lugares en Mixtepec recibieron su nombre según lo que relata la leyenda.

sourceDesc.bibl: Tu'un yata ñaña'a kua'in tsi inka chaa Mendoza Santiago, Francisco; Beckmann, Gisela Nieves, María M.. 2008. (2nd ed.).Instituto Lingüístico de Verano, A.C. Tlalpan, D.F., México Obtained from:

textDesc.channel: @mode:'w' means that the primary means of utilising this document is by reading it's written form;
textDesc.derivation: this document is labeled " original" because the XML-TEI markup of it's contents have not made any alterations to the original content;

list.item: Mixtec content found at following locations: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg/w

English translations are defined in relation to their Mixtec equivalents in the following location: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/spanGrp[@type='translation']/span[@xml:lang='en'] the value of //span[@target] is the pointer to the Mixtec translation equivalentwhere a preceding sibling is: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg

Spanish translations are defined in relation to their Mixtec equivalents in the following location: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/spanGrp[@type='translation']/span[@xml:lang='es'] the value of //span[@target] is the pointer to the Mixtec translation equivalent where a preceding sibling is: //text[@xml:lang='mix']/body/div/p/seg

elementSpec.desc: Where the page divisions in the original documents are, this encoding uses "div" (division) elements; this is to separate the linguistic, and knowledge data from formatting

projectDesc.ab: A recording of native speaker reading this text is in:

spanGrp.span: Here I tell an old tale about something that happened and what some people that lived a long time ago did.
There was a couple that lived together and the woman left and went away with another man.
what is this form? refine translation..
And then her husband got really mad.
Y su esposo se enojó mucho.
Then he grabbed a bow and arrow and climbed up a tall hill to where there was a town called Yuku Kuasa.
Y él agarró un arco y flecha y escaló una montaña alto adonde había un pueblo llamado Yuku Kuasa.
what is the function of "ña" here?
what is "kuasa"? Is this a real place?
There he kept watchover the path where she went with the other man.
Allí vigiló el camino para donde ella se fue con el otro hombre.
And that woman who went away left and arrived with the man she ran away with at a place where there were a lot of rocks lying around.
the man she ran away with
el hombre con quien se fue
There they ate avocados as they were there eating.
Allí comieron aguacates mientras comían allí.
And they left behind avocado pits, and now it's called "Krusi Tutichi".
Y dejaron atras huesos de aguacate, y ahora se llama "Krusi Tutichi".
They finished eating and they hit the road and left.
Acabaron de comer y daron el camino y se fueron.
this is more of a participle and isn't really inflected as shown in spanish
There it became hot, and then they arrived at a place where there was water gushing out, and they took out soap and they showered and washed their clothes.
Allí se calentó, y pues llegaron a un lugar donde agua salía a chorros, y sacaron sabón, y se ducharon y lavaron sus ropas.
got out (is this the same as "fly" or tone difference?)
usg of verb limited to domain of (clothes)
And there where they bathed and washed they left behind a place called Canama.
Y allí donde se ducharon y lavaron dejaron un lugar, el pueblo se llama Canama.
They finished bathing, finished washing clothes and then they hit the road and left again.
Acabaron de bañarse, acabaron de lavar ropas y pues daron el camino y se fue de nuevo.
They arrived at a plain where it was very beautiful.
Llegaron a una llanura donde era muy bonita.
is this a phrase or a proper compound
what is the exact translation here?
They came up to a large woods.
climbed up to (why no person inflection?) how to translate to spanish?
There they rested because they were very tired from walking on their feet.
Allí descansaron porque estaban muy cansados de caminar.
And the woman's husband was there at the edge of Yuku Kuasa keeping watch of the road, then he saw them walking.
Y el esposo de la mujer estaba a las afueras de Yuku Kuasa vigilando el camino, pues él les vio caminando
And there he saw that they came and were resting there in the shade. And then he shot the people when they were holding eachother.
There they laid, and they died.
And there blood spilled out below the tree and then they names the town "Red Plain"
is this inflected? is the lemma "ntsicha"?
is this "nii" 'old'? is the following "na" also part of this?
It is said that there sits a rock, a rock that is in an embrace, it is a rock laying in a town, called "Yoso Inkua'a".
what are the parts of this world?
This was the story of the woman who left with another man, that people told to us.
Is this really an expression meaning "all of us?" or is it "to us"?
And that's what I want to leave you with, so that the young people, the children, those that teach the children can tell them (the children) so that the tale in the language of our town isn't lost.
meaning? is this the same as "kustakoo"?
this has no "n-" why is is translated as past tense?
this is a derrogatory and dispreferred term. Should be replaced with "sa'an savi".
